com.eov.androidstomp

Class AndroidStomp

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.eov.androidstomp.AndroidStomp

  • public class AndroidStomp
extends java.lang.Object
    This method is the bare minimum to get a stomp client working over an ssl connection. Configuration of the queue to use BKS is also required if you need a secure connection. There are two simple methods: read and write. They both open and close a connection during every transaction. This works well in sketchy data areas but future users my wish to re-use the sockets. This MUST be complied with an android compatible version of JAVA (1.6) to work correctly. It took me too long to remember that :)

    • Constructor Detail

      • AndroidStomp

        public AndroidStomp(java.io.InputStream inputStream,
            java.lang.String passedInServer,
            java.lang.String trustStorePassword,
            int port,
            java.lang.String queueUserName,
            java.lang.String queuePassword)
        This is the constructor. It takes most of the values needed to send an receive messages.
        Parameters:
        inputStream - The location of the keystore/key to use for ssl, this must be generated outside of this jar
        passedInServer - The url of the message queue server
        trustStorePassword - The password for the device's truststore containing the key used for this ssl
        port - The server port for the stomp instance
        queueUserName - The userName to log on to the server
        queuePassword - The password to log on to the server

    • Method Detail

      • connect

        public java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> connect(java.lang.String server,
                                                           int port,
                                                           java.lang.String login,
                                                           java.lang.String pass)
                                                             throws java.io.IOException,
                                                                    javax.security.auth.login.LoginException
        Used to connect to the server This loads the inputstream with some content. It is the first thing that comes out when getMessage is called
        Parameters:
        server - URL of the server (www.example.com)
        port - The message queue port (61617)
        login - username for queue
        pass - password for queue
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        javax.security.auth.login.LoginException

      • sendMessage

        public boolean sendMessage(java.lang.String destination,
                  java.lang.String message)
                    throws java.io.IOException,
                           javax.security.auth.login.LoginException
        This method is used to send text data to a given queue, it creates a new connection, sends it's message and closes said connection It sends the pre-set begin message, the your message then the end values
        Parameters:
        destination - queue name prefaced with "/queue/"
        message - text string to send to the server
        Returns:
        true if method completes
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        javax.security.auth.login.LoginException

      • getMessage

        public java.lang.String getMessage(java.lang.String queue,
                          java.lang.String ack)
                            throws java.io.IOException,
                                   javax.security.auth.login.LoginException
        This method is used to create a connection, look for active messages, use them and then close the connection. The intent here is to not have this thing open for long, and, thus not be subject to most failures.
        Parameters:
        queue - the "/queue/..." to read from
        ack - the ack mode "client" or "auto"
        Returns:
        The message body from the waiting message
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        javax.security.auth.login.LoginException
